title: Should i file bankruptcy?
question: I have a private student loan that has placed levies on my accounts. Its about $20,000.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Nondischargeable debt and student loans,Bankruptcy and debt
answers: Student loans are rarely discharged in bankruptcy. A bankruptcy attorney might help you with Chapter 13 to get a manageable payment plan. A student loan lawyer can discuss non-bankruptcy options with. D.J. Rausa in San Diego and Jay Fleischman in Pasadena are good choices.

Private student loans are tricky business, but you do have options depending on where you went to school and what type of loan you have. If your bank account has been levied, that means you were served a lawsuit and they have obtained a judgment against you. I suggest you speak with a California Student Loan/Bankruptcy Lawyer for assistance.
I concur with the response by atty Areshenko and recommend you contact a Student Loan/bankruptcy specialist for help. I recommend D.J. Rausa in San Diego.

Student loans almost never get discharged except by way of a separate motions and meeting stringent requirements.
You need to have a meeting a with an attorney.
